data.text:
I have, but then I got drop bars that I could actually use. For a very long time, light + aero was all I cared about so I was looking Zipp Carbon, Easton EC90s, and 3T offerings....great bars, but the drop and reach measurements were really not good for me and my flexibility. As I got into longer and longer distance riding, I started paying more attention drop and reach numbers and start looking at smaller numbers and actually at the same time, wider bars. I'm 5'9 and I refuse to ride 42cm bars even on the road..44cm is as narrow as I'll go. To me, the most comfortable bar on the market right now is the Zipp XPLR70. The have a really shallow drop, some flare, some backsweep and short reach while being 46cm wide. Getting into the drops is very easy even while in a relaxed position. If you want to really do some research and compare bars, go to: https://whatbars.com/

data.text: Professional fitter here. If you're not using the drops then you might consider different drop bars or a fit adjustment. The whole purpose of drop bars is to offer three distinctly different riding positions, for different purposes. The drops are great for cornering and descending as they get more weight onto your front wheel and get your center of gravity lower. With a (typical gravel) flared bar you can also get a wider hand position for more control (see the trend towards wider and wider bars in MTB). Drops are also a great option for long drags into a headwind.

Go with a flatbar. Find something with a very shallow drop such as the Ritchey Beacon. The drop is almost insignificant but gives you more hand positions and stability. Learn to embrace the drops. It can take time and practice for them to become comfortable to use.

data.text: I've seen weight weenies trim the drops shorter to save a few grams. If you've tried a few setups and just don't like drops and/or are looking to save weight, then go with a flat bar. The shifters and bar alone would shave a hundred grams easy, if we're talking aluminum here. This is gravel, not super tight technical single track, so there's really no argument against using bar ends to give you extra hand positions. Quite frankly a flat bar with ends is most comfortable for me, might be worth a shot.
